newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan flirts with 8-yr low, then pulls back.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan flirts with 8-yr low, then pulls back.

text.p: The depreciating Taiwan dollar again tested longstanding support on Thursday, but last-minute U.S. dollar sales -- likely orchestrated by the central bank -- pulled it back to a slightly higher close, dealers said.

The local unit dived to as low as T$27.912 on active buying of the U.S. dollar by many interests, but the rate closed at its intraday high of T$27.890, virtually unchanged from Wednesday's T$27.891 finish.
Turnover through dealers was an active US$276 million.
"It really looks like the central bank's invisible hand is actively defending the Taiwan dollar, but it's difficult to prove," said one dealer at a foreign bank.
"The central bank has become very good at intervention."
The central bank defended the dollar at T$27.5 for years, but said in mid-1996 it was abandoning the policy, hinting a depreciation was welcome in the interest of stronger exports.

The Taiwan dollar has been on a long, slow decline since mid-January and recently has repeatedly flirted with T$27.9, prompting dealers to predict it would break support at $T28 in the second half -- but not until the central bank is ready.
A T$27.892 close would be the lowest since January 7, 1989.
Quarter-end commercial demand for the U.S. dollar and the U.S. dollar's recent general strength overseas were the main reasons for persistent buying of the greenbank, dealers said.
"With U.S. dollar demand continuing to be strong, the market will not give up testing the T$27.90 level on Friday," the dealer said. "But the central bank's attitude pretty much sets the rate."
The central bank appeared to be determined not to let the local unit fall below the T$27.90 support level at close for the time being, dealers said.
A range of T$27.89-92 was seen for Friday.
